text: SUNLIGHT, as bright and sharp as a blade, slicing down on this moonscape of SNOW and ICE. Feel the cold in your tee The wind makes a faint flute-sound and all else is silenc In the distance sit god-sized hills, hazy and dream-like. spread before them, abutting a black bristle of trees... A VILLAGE. Just a handful of buildings, looking like toy blocks dropped onto a clean white quilt. SUPER: Keelut, Alaska. How do people even survive out here? And why?

Not so much a backyard as an expanse between the distant TREELINE and a roughly-hewn LOG CABIN, smoking chimney an mossy walls, a soft rhythmic wump wump wump leading us to A BOY (7), kneeling to pack a small mound of snow. Wump, wump, wump. He looks swollen in his pillowed coat, workin well-used ARMY MAN into the mound. His name is BAILEY. His nose running, his breath clouding before his face, he wholly focused on this very serious work until... He looks up. Sees something. Freezes. A WOLF. Just emerged from the trees. Motionless. Yellow e fixed on Bailey, her own breath steaming. She’s huge. ON BAILEY, seen from behind, looking out at the WOLF, onl forty feet away. Watching him in silence.

A TEA KETTLE on a wood stove alllmost whistles but a FEMA HAND lifts it out of frame as we begin to... Drift through the space, catching the details. Three room with a small kitchen area. A low insulated ceiling with plastic sheets duct taped over the windows. A pair of FUR-LINED BOOTS, knee-high and heavy, wait by front door where an AR-15 RIFLE is propped in the umbrell stand. A child’s .22 RIFLE leans in the corner. A CB RADIO hangs from a peg next to the CLOSET DOOR with PADLOCK on it. No phone that we can see. There’s a ratty COUCH with unfolded laundry on it. A soot FIREPLACE smolders with a COMPOUND BOW hung above the man And like an afterthought, a CRUDE MASK rests on the mantl made of driftwood and pelt. A wolf face. We find the WOMAN, sitting very still in a threadbare cha wearing a thick wool sweater, an untouched cup of tea in lap. Her name is MEDORA SLONE (30). Underfed, distant, with striking white-blond hair and pale, grey-gold eyes. She's just staring. At nothing, it seems. The wind keens faintly outside. The house creaks. Finally, she looks up.
The heavy door opens inward and Medora peers out, hugging herself against the cold.

Over her shoulder, OUT THERE: that snow mound Bailey was making. And the action figure still stuck into it. But no Bailey. No nothing. Just the field of white, the fading daylight all the way to the darkness of the trees. CUT TO BLACK. IN BLACKNESS, A WOLF HOWL carries from some far unknowabl place...but then morphs into a DRONING ELECTRIC BUZZ... INT. KITCHEN - CORE’S HOME - NIGHT Which is a MICROWAVE, a TV dinner turning inside until it beeps! and MALE HANDS gingerly remove it.  INT. MAIN ROOM - CORE’S HOME - NIGHT A PAINTING OF A WOLF, an amateur work. From 0.S., we hear MAN, apparently leaving a voicemail message...
Hi, sweetheart. Uh. It’s me. Again. There are in fact several WOLF PAINTINGS here. Dozens. Different angles and settings but...the same animal?

I'd heard you got Associates, huh? I read that, Northern Light had a blurb on it. Tenure committee gets one right, at last. Heh. I’m uh...I am so proud of you. We drift over the DESK and COMPUTER, BOOKS and PAPERS hoa neatly. Titles like Canis Lupus Migration Study, American Nature Journal, Arctic Grey In Decline. An academic’s lai

I know you're busy, but...I hope we'll talk sometime. You can call whenever. I hope uh... Here’s a PHOTO OF A YOUNG BEARDED MAN in muddy camping ge grinning hugely, a caption on it: Yellowstone, 1979.

Anyway. I’m going to see your mother tomorrow. She sends her love. We find him in his overstuffed recliner, the TV muted, hi microwave dinner on a tray. His name is RUSSELL CORE (50s the guy from the photo. But there’s silver in his hair no more in his beard. This is a tired man. He carries ghosts
And...so do I. He holds the phone to his ear a beat longer...and hangs u Aims the remote, turns up the news a bit: Iraq, circa 200
..-while Coalition forces advanced on the town of Falujah under heavy fire... But Core isn’t really watching, is he?

Core sits in the steaming bathtub, the water to his chin. Staring at something. Grimly contemplating it. A RAZOR BLADE. Resting there on the edge of the tub. Wait He stares. Takes a deep breath for courage. Or maybe defe And reaches for the blade... His dripping hand hovers over it in sudden indecision. Th moment extends. Until... He retracts his hand after all. Leaves the razor there. Exhales and looks away.
It’s bright and sunny. Not the cold-diamond sunshine of Keelut but sunshine with some actual warmth. Trees are gr CORE’S COMPACT CAR pulls up, parks, and he heads inside.
As Core passes the Christmas-decorated DESK, the young NU in a Santa hat gives him a small, sweet smile.
Hi, Kelly.

Hi, Mr. Core. She’s having a good day. He smiles back, as best he’s able. INT. CORE’S WIFE’S ROOM - REST HOME - DAY A WOMAN'S HAND, gnarled into a frozen claw on a hospital It’s CORE’S WIFE, her mouth agape, eyes clamped shut to g the impression that she’s perpetually moaning. But she’s of course, she’s been paralyzed and unconscious for years Core sits bedside her, reading a novel. He bites a candy cane, the crunch! like a bone breaking in this quiet room A soft, involuntary glottal noise gurgles in his Wife’s throat. He looks up at her for a long beat but, when no o sound comes, he returns to his book.  INT. FOYER - CORE’S HOME - DAY THE PILE OF MAIL on the welcome mat is pushed aside as th front door opens and Core’s LIGHTWEIGHT HIKING BOOTS step He hangs up his windbreaker, drops his keys, bends with a grunt to collect the mail, pausing then to look at his-- ANSWERING MACHINE, with ‘0’ messages waiting for him. Which is deeply disappointing.

Core settles into his recliner, thumbing idly through the mail until...this one LETTER in particular. KEELUT, AK, reads the return address. A childlike scrawl. Confused, he opens it, unfolds the single page, begins to read. And the color drains from his face. MACRO ON THE LETTER, we’re reading it, ‘DEARMR CORE, THRE AGO MY SON BAILEY WAS TAKEN BY WOLVES’ even as we hear--
Dear Mr. Core, Three days ago my son Bailey was taken by wolves. He reads, horribly spellbound...

This happened twice already here. I tried to track them but could not. No one in the village will hunt them. I am alone here now. I have read your book. I know you have done this before. In my heart, I know that you are able to do it now. I do not expect you to find my son alive. But you could find his bones and maybe slaughter the wolf that took him. My husband will come home from the war soon. I must have something to show him. I can't just have nothing. I know you have sympathy for this animal. Please don't. Come and kill it to help me. My son's bones are in the snow. He sits there, surrounded by all those paintings.
Sincerely yours, Medora Slone. A stunned, silent beat. He refolds the letter, sets it aside. And looks away.

CORE’S HANDS, scrubbing vigorously under the sink. IN THE MIRROR, Core blots his brow, finds his own anxious eyes for a moment. Takes a deep breath and then, oddly... A MAN with luggage passes behind him. Oh. He’s not at hom
Core emerges from the MEN’S ROOM with his small rolling suitcase, heads towards the bustling CHECK-IN COUNTER.

JET NOISE drowns everything as we find Core in a window s dozing. His eyes slit open and, vaguely disoriented, he g out at the dreamy purple sky. And he’s holding MEDORA’S LETTER, folded into quarters.
Core moves through this minor almost-empty hub, passing s HUNTERS headed the other way.
Core fills out paperwork as the sullen CLERK provides key
Four wheel drive?
(‘of course’ ) Yessir.
And uh...GPS?
Where you headed?
Keelut.
GPS won’t work out there. Here... (passing him a MAP) ...this one the more accurate ones. Core regards the map and...

CORE’S RENTAL SUV drives away on a salt-crusted strip of that runs to infinity, brown-white tundras spreading to either side. The sky is an ominous golden-pink, like a great inverted refracting weird light. The truck grows small beneath it.

Core drives one-handed, uncertainly consulting the map an scanning for landmarks. Scanning for anything. The SUN remains low in the sky. Long shadows, fewer build to be seen, much more snow. He sees distant shapes of CARIBOU moving along frozen wat He sees WHIRLS of snowy wind, miniature sideways tornados He sees a LONE FIGURE in a DOG SLED whisking across the plains, drawn by a bounding team of HUSKIES. He drives onward. Medora’s FOLDED LETTER rides shotgun.

From afar, we see Core approach a TRUCKER at the pumps. Closer, Core shows the map, points questioningly to a cer point. The Trucker looks at it (check that eagle tattoo over his eye), shakes his head, chuckles wetly.

THIS ROAD is unpaved and snowy, so Core drives slow, hunc over the wheel. Drifts like seawalls rise on either side. He slows now, squinting-- THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD at the road curving upwards into a HILLY WOODED PASS, seeming to disappear before him. With a frustrated hiss he re-checks the map. Useless. He wipes his fogged-over window, scanning as he drives-- Wait. He stops suddenly.
THE SUV backs up, pausing beside a tree with a small RECTANGULAR SOMETHING nailed to it. Core rolls down his window for a better look at... The faded, hand-painted WOODEN SIGN. “Keelut.”

A TOTEM POLE rises into the sky: the carved faces of bear owls, dogs, and devils keeping solemn watch over all. Below it we find ILLANAQ (80s), looking out in watchful expectation. Filthy anorak, long braided hair. She’s Yup’ the indigenous people of Keelut. CORE’S RENTAL SUV appears slowly up the main (indeed, the only) road of Keelut, pausing now below the totem pole. He rolls down his window, calls up to her...
Excuse me... She just stares at him.
The Slone cabin? Her cracked-leather face splits into a smirk and...
(gesturing) At the end.  Core nods thanks, but warily, and drives on. Illanag watches him go.

The truck jounces on the rocky ground. Core scans the village, little more than two rows of buildings and the r between. Nobody’s out that doesn’t need to be. He sees: A-FRAMES and STURDY CABINS, solid and stubborn, every chi working, radio antennae spiking from every roof. Animal s tacked to doors and stacks of cordwood close by. SNOW-MOBILES and CHAIN-TIRED TRUCKS with electric blanket draped over their engines, nosed into massive muddy drift PLYWOOD KENNELS for teams of HUSKIES chained by their SLE indifferent to the cold, gnawing on bones. A FEW YUP’IK KIDS dart across the road, shouting. A TALL YUP’IK MAN (30s), his long hair drawn back into a ponytail, unloading supplies from his truck, scowling at as he passes. There’s a CHURCH, a SCHOOLHOUSE, a WOODEN WATER TOWER and sorry-looking PUB. The GENERATOR SHACK grumbles and smoke Pure functionality and self-reliance. Zero gloss. And now he sees it. Up ahead at the edge of Keelut, almos outside of Keelut...the SLONE CABIN.

The road ends. He parks and glances around before wading through knee-high snow up towards the cabin where... A RUSTY RED TRUCK is parked. Caribou antlers hang over th door. Maybe a welcome, maybe a warning. As he gets closer The door opens. Medora Slone appears, uncertainly, holdin dog-eared PAPERBACK BOOK to herself. A moment, the two of them looking at each other across th distance to her door. FROM OVER MEDORA’S SHOULDER, we see her lift the book, consult the AUTHOR’S PHOTO on the back: it’s that Yellows picture we saw in Core's house.  10. And just beyond it, there’s Core in the flesh, but stoope slightly and breathing hard as he approaches.

THE KITCHEN TABLE is stacked with dishes of food villager have brought: caribou soup, fry bread, pies and canned fr Core sits by the wood stove, a fresh cup of tea in his ha He looks up from those HEAVY FUR-LINED BOOTS in the corne stare uncomfortably across at-- Medora, who sits on the couch, straight-backed, unblinkin
I didn’t think you’d really come. When I wrote you I was...I guess I was going to try anything.
I’m uh...I am very sorry about your son, Mrs. Slone
(re: book) Canis lupus.
Yes, ma’am.
“Apex predator.” What’s that mean?
It means they’ve been around a long time and know how to hunt better than we do.
You’ve come to kill it? To kill the animal that took him?
I came to help if I can. To explain this if I can.
The explanation is we’re cursed here. The only help is to kill it.
I’m just a writer.  11.
You’ve hunted and killed one before. That’s what you wrote. He winces at that statement, it actually pains him. She h him the book as if to say, See? He turns it over...
Where'd you find this? A Year Among Them, it’s called, wolves on the cover.
It found me. I don’t know how. It was just here one day. Says that in the same tone as, At the bookstore. He reset
You mentioned his bones. She looks down, brow furrowed, chewing her lip. Thinking.
I was thinking they'd show after breakup. You know...the thaw. She stares off at the RIFLE in the corner, unseeing..
I would have killed the thing myself, if I could have found it. Goddamn demon. Goddamn murderer. I tried to find it. Core shakes his head gently, sets his tea down.

The pack could be eight or ten members. You don’t want to find that. They stare at each other a while, until Core notices something, and she turns to see what he’s looking at... THAT CRUDE WOLF MASK, forgotten there on the hearth.
A shaman’s mask. Someone brought it here. (back to Core) Can I ask you a personal question? (off his nod) Do you have a child?  12.
A daughter. In Anchorage, she teaches at the university.
A teacher like her father.
I’m no teacher. Maybe I could have been but...she’s good at it. She wanted to be an Alaskan.
That city’s not Alaska. Something in her tone there, something dark.
(quietly) Do you have any idea what’s out those windows? How black it gets? How that black gets into you? Let me tell you Mr. Core, you’re not on Earth here.
(rattled by that) But...this is your home.
I was brought here when I was a child, that makes me not from here.
From where?
I don’t remember. I never asked. (beat, out the window) I don’t understand what they’re doing here.
Who?
Wolves.
They live here.  13.
(gesturing, this cabin) But I don’t understand what they’re doing here. Why is this happening to me? Why now?

They’re hungry, ma’am. No one’s cursed. It’s just biology. She leans back from his words. Insulted, perhaps. CORE (CONT’D) I’m sorry. I don’t know why this is happening to you. (beat) Does your husband know yet?
Men were supposed to call him. I can’t tell him while he’s there. He’1ll see what has happened when he comes home, what we’ve done, what no one was able to stop.
Why wouldn’t anyone hunt them after what happened? You said...two other children were...?
They're afraid. Or they think we deserve it.
I don’t understand that.
Stay here a while. You might. He struggles for the next thing to say. It takes him a bi
You’re not alone.
Yes, I am. Come, I’1ll show you where the children were taken. As she stands, she looks sourly at his feet...
Are those your only boots?  14.
These are what I have.
You’1l need better boots.

CORE NOW WEARS THE HEAVY FUR-LINED BOOTS, tromping throug the snow with Medora, behind the village. Their crunching footfalls are like a heartbeat. K-knch, k-knch, k-knch. They pass by HEAVY EQUIPMENT kept behind cabins: overturn canoes, gas augers to drill lake ice, shovels and chainsa But hills and the forest sweep before them, eerily majest
It’s beautiful.
You don’t understand.
But you're happy here? You were?

That’s not a question I ask myself. I see pictures in magazines, vacation pictures with sand and girls in bathing suits. Seems so strange to me. (gesturing into the woods) There’s a hot springs, not so far, a few hours walking. That’s as close as I can get to warmth.
A hot spring sounds good right now.

(absently) Good place to get clean. He wonders at her until nearing ENGINE NOISE prompts him look out at... A WHITE-HAIRED YUP’IK MAN and his YOUNG BOY rumbling by o SNOWMOBILE in low gear, both with rifles, pulling a dead MOOSE CALF on a sled. Passing in a powdery swirl, they stare at Core.  15.
As Medora and Core crest a low rise and inch sideways dow towards the ice...
You met your husband in this village?
I never met him anywhere. I knew him my whole life, I don’t have a memory he isn’t in. Something bitter comes into her voice, hissing almost--
And he left me here with a sick child.
Well...the war.
Someone on the radio said it’s not a real war.
It’s real enough. People are dying.
He said he’d never leave me. Words can’t be worthless like that. They stop there and she points out across the pond.
That's where the first boy was taken. OUT THERE, snowy wind skirls over the surface of the pond the WOODS beyond looming in shadow.
After that, they had men with rifles on the high points. And they walked the children to school. But it didn’t matter for Bailey.
Medora and Core stand atop the hill as the day fades into greyish half-light.  16.
The second was a girl, here. Cheeon’s daughter. She was sledding and the wolf came from behind her. Core glances behind them, then up at the disappearing sun
From the North, again. (back to her) Does Cheeon live nearby?
Yes. My husband’s friend.
Do you suppose I could speak with him? She makes a noise, an unhappy little snort.
No. I don’t suppose you could. So Core tries to move on from that...
Did uh...did Bailey like to sled?
No. He wasn’t the right one.
I’m...not sure what that means. But it’s like she didn’t even hear him. Just staring out.
You said he was sick?
He stopped going to school after my husband left.
That sounds normal.
There was nothing normal about my son.  17.
I just meant...my daughter went through that when she was Bailey's age. She flinches, looks away. CORE (CONT’D) I’m sorry. That’s not what--
Stop apologizing to me. (back to him) How did it feel to shoot that female wolf?
I had no choice. But it felt very bad.
Even though she'd taken a child, too? (off his reluctant nod) Because you think it’s the natural order? He chooses his words more carefully.
They're not what you think, Mrs. Slone. Wolves attacking people, that’s not...what happened here does not happen.
What happened here happened to me. She turns and trudges off. He stands there a moment, looking down the hill where all those sled tracks crisscross and interlace.

Core sits by the stove, slurping the last of some hot sou mopping the bowl with fry bread. As he sets it aside... Medora appears before him, hands him a CIGARETTE and MATC and then a CHOCOLATE BAR. She watches as he lights the smoke, takes a drag, has a b of chocolate. Savoring all of it.  18.
(re: the cigarette) I'd quit when my daughter was born but...
Will she expect you home soon?
(sadly admitting) I don’t know what she expects of me these days. She glances at the WEDDING BAND on his finger.
What about your wife? He seems to notice it for the first time. Smiles sadly.
She's alright without me. She considers him for a beat, and then...
I have a quilt and pillow for you. I can see you're tired. I...I can’t pay anything.

Oh, the chocolate’s fine. But that intended deadpan humor was totally lost on her, just blinks at him. So he tries gentle sincerity instead- CORE (CONT’D) It’s not important. She regards him curiously a moment and...
Good night, Mr. Core. He watches her drift away and close the bedroom door. Cli

THE ELECTRIC HEATER ticks, glows infernal orange in the d From somewhere else, a VOICE. Barely audible but...angry. On the couch, curled under a heavy quilt, Core blinks awa What is that? He looks to--  19. THE BEDROOM DOOR, open just a crack, spilling light. He gets up, crosses the room in his thermals, leans in so SLICE OF LIGHT falls over one eye as he sees-- INTO THE BEDROOM, where Medora sits in the STEAMING BATHT purposefully scrubbing her back with a hard brush. Her sk is rubbed raw and she MUTTERS angry, unknowable words. Ashamed, Core drops his eyes and backs away. He returns to the couch, gets under the quilt and rolls o to face away from the bedroom. But then... He hears the DOOR open. Hears quiet FOOTSTEPS in the room Rolls back over to see... MEDORA, glistening wet, naked by the window, tearing away plastic so the room now swells in ghastly blue moonlight. She turns to face him. She has the WOLF MASK on her face. He stares at her a long moment, terrified and heartbroken utterly unsure what to do. She removes the mask, drops it carelessly. Goes to him. P the quilt back, slips under the covers, facing out. He tries to give her space but there’s nowhere for him to She pulls his arm over her, above the covers. So he holds her like that, two spoons, unable to see the she stares out at the moonlight. Pleadingly? It’s not sex, just warmth. But then, slowly, she guides h HAND up to her THROAT...and holds it there. Tightly. Like willing him to squeeze as her tears spill in silence. Together, they gaze out the WINDOW...

PULLING OUT from the WINDOW until we find...A MAN, very still. Just standing there, a ways back from the cabin. His cigarette flares, the brief glow revealing his face. the YUP’IK MAN we saw before, the tall one with the ponyt His name is CHEEON. Watching the cabin from the darkness. FADE TO BLACK. IN BLACKNESS, the faraway cracks of EXPLODING SHELLS and.  20.

A CITY BURNS IN THE DISTANCE. A horizon of jagged smolder teeth, great slow plumes of smoke climbing into the sky. TILTING DOWN until the faceless face of A SOLDIER fills t frame. In his goggles and dust mask he looks insectile, alien, manning the .50 CAL TURRET atop a SPEEDING HUMVEE. whole world vibrates. VRRRRRRM. UP AHEAD OF THEM, appearing for milliseconds then disappearing again in gusts of road dust, a FLEEING PICKU TRUCK. Glimpses of head-wrapped FIGHTERS in the back. The HUMVEE accelerates. The SOLDIER sights along his .50. UP AHEAD, the TRUCK swerves and fishtails, FLIPS AND ROLL Surreal, because we can’t hear it happen, but we see BODI flying away from the tumbling wreck like dolls. The HUMVEE screeches to a halt ten yards out. The overtur TRUCK ignites into FLAMES. Doesn’t explode, just burns. A BURNING MAN scrambles away from the wreck, waving his a THE SOLDIER tracks him for a beat, two beats, and then-- BRAAAPT. THE .50 ROARS, chops the man down, cleaving limb if with an invisible axe. TRACER ROUNDS like burning thre ANOTHER MAN staggers towards them out of the smoke, bleed moaning soundlessly, wildly FIRING his Kalashnikov. PING!PING! SHELLS RICOCHET off the Humvee, the SOLDIER pivots, fires a prolonged blast. BRAAAAAAAAPT. Destroys the man, sweeps the area, chews the truck, ends In the ensuing smoke-swirling silence, a GRINNING CORPORA hops out of the Humvee, trots towards the spread of carna The .50 Soldier lowers his mask, lifts his goggles to rev a pair of blank pale eyes. This is VERNON SLONE (27), lit and powerful, calmly lighting a cigarette as-- OUT THERE, the Corporal kneels over a child-sized BODY, adjusting it, bringing something out of his pack... Slone smokes. Watches. OUT THERE, the Corporal takes a grinning selfie with his CAMERA, flashing the peace sign, posing with the CORPSE.  21. Slone smokes. Watches.
Smoke. Rubble. Post-battle chaos. HEAVY ARMOR moving thro Slone stalks along: helmet, body armor, M-4 CARBINE at lo ready.
He turns down this narrow passage, alert, searching. He pauses, like sensing the air. Hears something. Moves.

A soft WHIMPER and a GRUNT, some kind of STRUGGLE out of focus in the foreground as Slone appears in the doorway. That same CORPORAL has his pants down, thrusting himself an IRAQI WOMAN bent over a desk. Unh, unh, unh. From across the room, the Woman makes terrified eye conta with Slone, who has no reaction at all other than to brie double-check out the doorway and then-- BAM. Shoot the Corporal between the shoulder blades. He spills off the Woman, gasping and bleeding on the floor. The Woman scuttles back, more terrified now. Trapped. Expressionless, Slone draws his KA-BAR KNIFE, steps forwa She inhales to scream but...he holds out the KNIFE to her handle first. She’s astonished. Shaking, she takes it. He tips his head towards the Corporal. Nods.

TRACKING BACK with Slone as he walks calmly but briskly a EXT. MAIN STREET —- CONTINUOUS TRACKING HIM as he returns to the churn of activity, VEHI and SOLDIERS wiping the background. He keeps moving, unperturbed, though the DIN of this place is suffocating. STILL TRACKING HIM, a long shot, all the way down the blo as the NOISE builds to a feverish intensity until--  22.

IN SLONE’S NECK WITH A MIST OF RED. We stay with him as he collapses, semi-conscious, bleedin IN THE BACKGROUND, we glimpse SOLDIERS FIRING at the unse sniper, OTHERS rushing up to Slone. All in total silence. He just lays there, blinking glassily as we...
Only a few frames of him, a wisp, staring at us with his faintly blue skin.
As the others roughly lift him out of frame, Slone seems be trying to say something.

TIGHT ON SLONE as SOUND comes back, his eyes fluttering o his neck now THICKLY BANDAGED, dried blood in his blond h A MEDIC is wheeling him on a STRETCHER, urgent and confus activity all around, WIND and SHOUTING and HELICOPTER ROT
(shouting over the noise) Slone, you lucky fucker!
(a weak rasp) ...B-Bailey?

You'll see him soon, buddy! You're going home! The MEDIC thrusts Slone’s PAPERWORK to a harried TRANSPO OFFICER as Slone is loaded into a waiting MEDICAL COPTER he’s already lapsing back into unconsciousness... FADE TO BLACK. IN BLACKNESS, a terrible RIPPING noise...  23.

Which is Medora pulling off a length of DUCT TAPE, which then wraps around the barrel of the AR-15. Across the room, Core again pulls on SLONE’S HEAVY BOOTS. Medora opens a duffel, unpacks a CARIBOU-HIDE SUIT: a thi and heavy one-piece covering, like a hooded poncho. She presents it to Core as weak light simmers outside.

Core steps outside in the caribou suit, a PACK and the AR slung over his shoulders, SNOWSHOES on the big boots. Behind him, Medora cinches her robe. A light dusting of S is falling. Core looks up at it, shudders...
So much for ‘too cold to snow.’
What’s that mean?
Just something I heard.

It’s never too cold to snow. (glancing up) There’s something wrong with the sky. He gives her a look, consults the COMPASS he’s holding in THICKLY-GLOVED HAND. North, the needle shows. He nods to her. She nods back. And... From afar, we see Core trudge away from the cabin, toward where that wolf came from, and Medora disappears back ins

location: WOODS AT THE EDGE OF KEELUT

text: Core moves along, head down, making good time. But slowin he sees something ahead... Glimpsed through a spiderweb of branches, a FIGURE and a FIRE, some kind of SMALL HUT.  24. Closer, he realizes it’s ILLANAQ. She’s burning trash ite in an oil drum, another FIRELIGHT glowing inside her hut. Drawing up to her, she speaks without looking at him...
You know the name of this village?
Keelut.
Say its meaning.
I don’t know its meaning. Now she looks at him, that nasty teeth-missing grin.
“Evil spirit disguised as dog. Or wolf.”
Why would they name it that?
(shrugs, returns to her work) You’re the wolf expert, I hear. Annoyed and discomfited, Core continues on past her. She calls to his back...
That girl knows evil. She’1l tell you.
(without stopping or turning back) What that girl knows is grief. Have a good day, ma’am.
You're going the wrong way. Go back the way you came. He ignores her and she watches him fade into the woods.  25.

VERY WIDE, Core is barely a speck out there, an ant scoot across a dimension of white. Beautiful landscape, terrify in its vastness. CLOSER, Core stomps through drifts, wearing GOGGLES now, sinking slightly despite the snowshoes. Winded, he pauses and turns in a full slow circle, taking this place, catching his breath. He consults the compass and continues.

Core gulps thirstily from his thermos, drains it and then packs snow in to refill it. He gnaws on some jerky. He bends at the waist, stretching out his legs and back a best he can before re-shouldering his pack and the rifle.

A THICK MIST wafts across frame as Core enters this clear his head tilting in confusion because... The snow is all melted here, a circular area of wet bare ground that radiates from a HILLSIDE CAVE up ahead, the m of which issues a steady trickle of STEAM. That momentary stutter in his stride must be him recogniz this place from Medora’s words. He approaches...

And from deep within this steamy slick-walled darkness, w see Core’s silhouette bend into view, peering in. His hea breathing echoes, mixes with a steady drip-drip-dripping. He glances down, sees... A HARD WHITE SUBSTANCE, frozen in rivulets through the cr of the cave floor. Is that wax? He wonders at this a moment...and continues on his way.  26.

Core walks slow, face flushed, ice crusting his beard. Hi breath billows raggedly. He scans the forest floor... But the snowy surface is perfectly unbroken. No tracks. Even behind the goggles, he looks discouraged. He continu

THE SUN shrieks down, directly overhead. Core shuffles in view, stoop-shouldered, exhausted. He clambers awkwardly to a low exposed boulder and sits/collapses. Gulps deep breaths and slips off his pack rifle, raises the goggles. He rests, bent forward, eyes shut. Wincing. We hold on hi long beat as his breathing slowly settles until... A HOWL. His eyes snap open. He straightens, looks over hi shoulder. It was faint but unmistakable: wolves.

CORE’S FACE inches over the crest, wide-eyed, looking out THE SNOWY PLAIN spreading before him after the STEEP DROP directly below: a great, dead valley floor. And far out there, strange against the frozen stillness o all, there are TINY MOVING SHAPES. He puts his FIELD GLASSES to his eyes and... CORE’S BINOCULAR POV shows a PACK OF SNARLING GREY WOLVES six or eight, hackles up, hard to say exactly how many th way they’re darting and thrashing around something. Core crawls to a better vantage point and looks again. (A was that a flash of actual excitement in his eyes?) CORE’S BINOCULAR POV now shows a better angle of the WOLV the pink fur around their mouths...and the WOLF PUP CARCA they're fighting over, ripping apart, gobbling down. With the field glasses still to his eyes, we can see in Core’s mouth how whatever excitement he felt turns sour. He lowers the glasses, holds there, looking off as the BARKING and HOWLING of the wolves come echoing in.  27. And finally, he looks away and begins to scoot back the w he came except--

head_text.subj: HE LANDS HARD WITH AN INVOLUNTARY CRY OF PAIN--

text: AND FAR OUT ON THE PLAIN, the ALPHA WOLF hears that. Look back towards the ridge, tall ears straightening. AT THE BASE OF THE DROP-OFF, Core struggles up out of the snow, GRUNTING painfully, battered. And quickly realizing He's lost the AR-15. He swats at his shoulders but it’s g He looks all around him in the tufts of disturbed snow ma by his fall. Oh Jesus, where is it? And then... A STRONG GUST OF WIND BLOWS FROM BEHIND CORE, ruffling th fur on his hood, gusting the SNOW about him-- WHICH WE FOLLOW AS IT SPEEDS OUT ACROSS THE PLAIN. We are wind and we’re blowing right up to-- THE WOLVES, the rest of which all look in the same direct as the Alpha, back towards Core. Their noses twitch and a collective GROWL rumbles from the pack. ON CORE, even three hundred feet away he’s able to tell t the Wolves have stopped feasting and are now clocking him He stares out at them, frozen in rapidly mounting fear. THE ALPHA GROWLS, long teeth exposed, eyes wild and fixed CORE catches something in his periphery, look-- THE AR-15, jammed into the snow barrel-first, ten feet aw This moment: Core and the Pack facing each other over the plain. No motion. No sound but their soft GROWLS in the w CORE LUNGES, clawing through snow for the rifle. THE PACK CHARGES, bounding at him with the force of rocke BIRD'S EYE VIEW OF THE PLAIN, that speck on the left is C the cluster rapidly approaching from the right are Wolves  28. CORE snags the rifle, jerks it out, tugs at the DUCT TAPE around the barrel but his bulky GLOVES make it impossible THE WOLVES, charging in, snouts low, huge paws churning s CORE sees this, frantically gnaws a glove off and pulls t duct tape loose bare-handed. IN THE DISTANCE, the Wolves are quickly growing larger. A hundred fifty feet away, a hundred now and-- CORE shoulders the rifle, his one bare hand already numbe with cold, shaking it out-- BIRD'S EYE VIEW as the Wolves fan out into a C-shape, clo on Core. They're going to encircle him. CORE shakes his numb hand and sights though-- THE RIFLE SCOPE, where the Alpha is gigantic but the CROSSHAIRS jump and jerk-- CORE lowers the rifle, inhales to steady himself as we--
CORE’S DRIPPING HAND In the bathtub the other night, hovering over that razor.

CORE keeps the rifle down, eyes off, deciding something. THE WOLVES are so very close now. BIRD’S EYE VIEW as that C-shape nearly surrounds Core. CORE lifts the rifle and his manner can only be described regretful as he sights though-- THE RIFLE SCOPE, where the Alpha is seemingly right there HIS FINGER tightens on the trigger. THE ALPHA snarls and slavers, almost close enough to leap At the last second CORE LIFTS THE RIFLE SLIGHTLY--

head_text.subj: IN THE SCOPE THE CROSSHAIRS MOVE OFF THE ALPHA AND--

text: THE ALPHA JERKS TO A HALT, stymied by the sudden report. BIRD'S EYE VIEW as the C-shape of wolves slows, stops. CORE AIMS OFF AND FIRES AGAIN. BAM. THE ALPHA JERKS BACK AS THE BULLET PUNCHES THE SNOW. Pft. CORE shivers in place. BIRD'S EYE VIEW as the C-shape of wolves disintegrates an spreads away from him. CORE keeps the rifle up, watching down its barrel. THE ALPHA gives a last uncertain look his way before trot off. The rest of the PACK follows. CORE slowly lowers the rifle, watching them go, stupefied his eyes swimming. WIDE ON CORE, very small out there, hunched, alone.

THE SUN is sinking, bruising the sky. WIDE ON CORE, returning slowly over familiar landscape. CLOSER ON CORE, deeply fatigued, finishing his thermos as treks onward. He’s following his own tracks back the way he came, weavi along parallel to them. He looks absolutely bereft.
Core returns in gloom. The buildings of Keelut glow weakl ahead. His eyes are downcast, snowshoes crunching dolorou

Core enters through the back, half-stumbling in and then leaning his whole weight on the door to close it again. He drops the pack, sets the rifle down, sits before the fireplace full of dying embers and removes the snowshoes, wriggles out of the caribou suit.
Mrs. Slone.  30. He sits there a moment, breathing the warm air, returning himself. But she doesn’t respond. CORE (CONT’D) Mrs. Slone? Silence. Something feels wrong.
Creeak. Core pushes the door open with a fingertip, peeks DRAWERS have been dumped out, most of the clothes gone. T shallow WARDROBE is open, empty hangers inside.

Core comes back into the main room, wondering, when he se THE CLOSET DOOR, with the PADLOCK unlocked and dangling f the hasp. He opens it...not a closet at all but in fact a ROOT CELL with steep earthen steps leading down into harsh pale lig

A SINGLE BARE BULB dangles from the low ceiling. Core comes carefully down the steps, stooped to keep from bumping his head, taking in the space: Wooden crates. Mason jars of dried foods. Lumber, visquee rodent droppings on the floor. And something else. Core stares at it, his breath fogging of him as a confused kind of horror pools on his face. He steps forward. Tucked upright into a shadowy nook, there is some kind of PLASTIC-WRAPPED COCOON. He seems to already know what it It’s Bailey. Core folds the plastic back to see his face. Frozen, blue mouth ajar as if to inhale, eyes half-lidded and iced ove Core wants to scream but doesn’t know how.  31. As gently as he can, he removes the plastic-wrapped bundl the boy’s body and lays it on the floor of the cellar. He finds a FOLDED BLANKET and carefully covers Bailey up. He sits on a crate beside it and weeps.
Core stumbles down the main road, hollering left and righ
On either side, he sees curtains draw back in CABIN WINDO and SHADOWY FORMS appear there, looking out at him.

Up ahead, PEOPLE are emerging from their homes, trickling suspiciously into the road. A VILLAGER comes jogging up to him, glaring in alarm, a r in one hand, shrugging into his coat. It’s Cheeon. Core gestures wildly back over his shoulder--

--and Cheeon sprints past him, up towards the Slone cabin Core sways in the road, dizzied, looking at the VILLAGERS Some are Yup’ik, some are white, some mixed. Odd clashing clothes: animal hide mukluks and NFL jackets, like that. None of them say a word, none of them betray any emotion. Core just stands there shaking his head until he notices. ILLANAQ, at the rear of the crowd. He points at her...
Y-you knew, didn't you?
How could an old woman know?
How could you not say anything? Under her breath, as she turns and hobbles away...  32.
Go away. Leave us to the devils. He watches her go as OTHER VILLAGERS brush past him, up towards the cabin. Aching and cold, he follows.

Cheeon is kneeling over Bailey’s body, looking down on hi with a simultaneous expression of rage and boredom. There DARK BRUISE visible on the boy’s throat, encircling it. He replaces the blanket, stands (having to stoop low, tal he is) to face the Villagers and Core waiting behind him.
Where is Medora Slone? Nobody answers. Cheeon points at Core, specifically.
Where is she? Core shakes his head, helpless, and Cheeon snaps a comman

[Yup’ik words] --to a YUP’IK TEENAGER who dutifully sprints away up the stairs. Cheeon glares at Core a beat, then pushes past hi Some Villagers pause to say SOFT YUP’IK WORDS over the bo then they all file away as well, leaving Core there.

They’d left the front door open when they departed. Core emerges from the cellar and closes it again. He stands th unsure what to do... He goes to the fire, adds some logs, stokes it back to li Sinks onto the couch like an old building collapsing. He tips his head back...allows his eyes to close...

Core jerks awake to HUSHED VOICES. There are people here.  33. TWO WHITE MEN stand by the cellar door, looking askance a him in their heavy coats and hunter’s caps. They have Sheriff's badges: a FAT DEPUTY and a YOUNG DEPUTY. And now a THIRD MAN emerges from the cellar, running a ti hand over his face. Buzz cut, pale skin: his name is DETECTIVE DONALD MARIUM (43). He says something inaudible to his Deputies and then make kind of sympathetic eye contact with Core across the room
Marium has pulled up the chair to sit across from Core, b have coffee but neither one is drinking.
Why did she ask you here?
I don’t know. She’d read my book on wolves.
And you decided to come, why?

To help. She said wolves had taken children and no one would help. Here, see...? He thrusts out MEDORA’S LETTER, almost begging. As Marium unfolds and reads it, the two Deputies re-enter the cabin with a black VINYL BAG and descend into the cellar.
Well...no wolf took Bailey. (re-folding the letter) I need to keep this, okay? Core gestures, sure.
What’d you do out there?
I looked for the wolves.
Uh huh. Did you see them? Core nods, his mind far away.  34.
What’d you do?
(barely audible) Nothing. After a moment, Core seems to return, blinks at Marium. CORE (CONT’D) Are the others coming?
Others?
Investigators. Shouldn’t there be more investigators?
It’s not like TV here. It’s just us. We don’t have full membership with the rest of the world and mostly we like it that way.
Is it midnight yet?
It’s six p.m.
That can’t be, it...it was dark when I returned--
That was three-thirty p.m. Dawn is at ten a.m. now, you’re not acclimated. Core shakes his head, looking off, confused and brittle.
(softly) She strangled him.
Someone did.
It was her. Her truck is gone. She packed. She left me here to find him.  35.
Why would she do that?
(abruptly furious) “Why? Why?!” You're the police! Marium waits as Core settles down, embarrassed. CORE (CONT’D) I apologize.
No need.
I uh...I put a blanket on him.
We'll take good care of Bailey. Don’t you worry about that.
Someone has to tell the father.
We’ve sent word.
You know him? Marium nods slowly, his jaw becoming very tight.

If you’re from around here, you know Vernon Slone. Soft SCUFFING sounds behind them. Core looks... The Deputies are bringing the BODY BAG out of the cellar. INT. QUICK DOG MOTEL - “IN TOWN” - NIGHT MARIUM’S TRUCK pulls up to this grey rectangular slab, ag in sodium-yellow light, leading CORE’S SUV in to park. Core gets out of his vehicle, pausing there as Marium low his window, passes him an OFFICIAL FORM from a clipboard.
You'll need to stay a few days, at least. (MORE )
We'll probably have more questions and I'll need this statement from you. Just use your own words, short and sweet. Clete in there’s a notary. Core nods in tired acceptance and as he turns away...
You're sure she did this, but tell me how.
With a rope. I don’t know.
Not how she did it, how you know she did it. Core squints at Marium, suddenly alert.

Do you suspect me? Marium gives a diplomatic smile/frown, Nah, relax. But Core does not relax. He stares out into the night, th at the statement form in his hand, shaking his head. CORE (CONT’D) You asked me before about the wolves. When I encountered them, they were in the act of devouring one of their own. Just a pup. It’s not uncommon at all. At this, Marium seems to frost over.
In certain animal populations, when resources are scarce, when there is unnatural stress, some of the young may be killed off to preserve the group. The behavioral term for this is ‘savaging.’
We're not talking about animals, Mr. Core. Core shrugs, carelessly...
If you say so.  37. A beat, the two men facing each other in the lot.
Okay. Get some rest now... As Core turns away and Marium puts the truck in gear...
.»-maybe a hot bath or something. Get the chill off. He watches Core trudge stoop-shouldered into the motel without looking back. FADE TO BLACK. IN BLACKNESS, a gurgling WHITE NOISE builds...

A PAIR OF WELL-WORN HIKING BOOTS sit on a leafy, brown fo floor. No snow? Next to them, a PAIR OF KID’S BOOTS. Leaning against a tree, a .30-06 REMINGTON RIFLE, and bes it, a LIGHTWEIGHT .22. TWO PAIRS OF BARE FEET dangle in a SHALLOW CREEK. That’s gurgling we hear. It’s Vernon Slone: healthy, uninjured, smoking. Beside hi eating a cold egg sandwich in wax paper, is Bailey. So th is some other time. Their conversation is full of pauses.
(re: the creek) It’s cold.
Yep.
Mama said you’re going away.
You remember what deployment means? (off Bailey's frown) It means work. It means money for us.
For my birthday I’1l be seven.  38.
I know. I'll be home when you’re seven and a half. Slone gestures and Bailey looks off at... THE DEAD FAWN on the bank, a fresh bullet hole in her nec
How did that feel? Bailey stares at the fawn, glassily. Emptily, even. His answer is soft...
It felt real good. But then the boy’s brow furrows...
What?
You killed a person before.
Who told you that?
Mama. Slone doesn’t respond to that, just waits for more.
Who did you kill?
A man who would hurt Mama and you.
But he didn’t hurt us?
No. I hurt him first.
My teacher said it’s bad to kill people.
You'll hear that a lot.
So...it’s good?  39.
If you have to.
Why?
To protect what you love and what you need. Bailey considers these words seriously, then returns to h sandwich. As Slone reaches out to touch the boy’s hair...
When I go away...I’1ll always be with you. Do you understand that?
(not unkindly) Don’t lie. a miniscule twitch which on him reads Slone smiles at that, like a klieg light. As a SNAPPING noise builds we..
It’s a flustered MILITARY DOCTOR flipping through pages o his clipboard, looking for some answer and not finding it

I’m sorry. You should have been told before. Slone sits on the bed in his civvies in this bright clean room. His neck is NEWLY BANDAGED. He’s gaunt, pale, stari at the Doctor the way one stares at a leak in the ceiling
We have an SFAC rep coming over. Or if you'd prefer clergy...
Slone walks quickly, robotically, eyes dead ahead. No expression. No baggage. Hands thrust into his coat pocket  40.

Cheeon stands next to the baggage carousel, himself resembling the Keelut totem pole. Slone approaches and, by way of a greeting, Cheeon hands a SHEATHED BOWIE KNIFE, which Slone tucks under his coat the small of his back. No words, no handshake... They just continue on towards the exit, side by side. INT. CHEEON’S TRUCK (MOVING) - NIGHT The RADIO plays an upbeat country number and Cheeon drive them out of the AIRPORT PARKING LOT as Slone cracks the window, lights a cigarette, stares out at the darkness.

A NOVELTY PAINTING of a moose wearing red lipstick and a Marilyn Monroe wig. Cheeon stares at this as if pondering a calculus equation Slone sits at the table, smoking, staring blankly at-- Russell Core, who sits slouched in the corner, unable to Slone’s gaze, dabbing his runny nose with a tissue. It’s a little drop-ceiling room: hard furniture, coffee a stale donuts on the counter. After a quiet beat...
Are those my boots? Core looks down, swallows as he remembers that they are.
Yes.
You’re the one found my boy?
Yes. Slone exhales smoke, stubs the cigarette out, nods slowly
Thank you. Core doesn’t know how to respond.  41. Marium and the two Deputies enter: all three, to varying degrees, are visibly nervous in Slone’s presence.

We got leads, Vern. Got her picture out, been in touch with the Mounties, we're coordinating. We’re gonna find her. She’ll answer for it. Marium shoots the Deputy a look, Cool it. Cheeon looks from them to Slone, who listens to all this without expression.
Vernon. You have my--all of our deepest condolences. This is...I can’t even imagine. Slone nods in acceptance, lights a new smoke. Marium clea his throat.

Mr. Core was called here by your wife. He was the last one to see her and he’s been very helpful to us so far. We asked him to be here in case you had questions for him. Cheeon looks at Core. Slone looks at Core. Eventually...
Can you raise the dead?
No, sir.
Then I have no questions for you. Core looks away. Everyone except Slone and Cheeon shifts uncomfortably.
Can you think of anyone she might run to? Relatives? A friend? Anything at all? Slone pulls a long drag, really thinking...but finally ha shake his head No. And then he looks up at Marium..
Now?  42. Marium’s face clouds over.

Alright. INT. “COLD ROOM” - MORGUE - NIGHT Slone approaches the steel table with a sheet-covered something resting atop it in a bright pool of light. His is ever impassive...but he’s breathing faster than usual. Marium and the two Deputies stand back by the door. The CORONER waits for a subtle look from Marium and then draws back the sheet. We don’t need to see Bailey. We hold on Slone’s face. We hear his breath rattle inside his nose. We can see the ti clench of his jaw. In time, he’1l begin to sob.

Core is waiting outside on the church-pew bench when, fro inside the DOUBLE DOORS marked Restricted, comes a SCREAM anguished and bitter it barely sounds human. It startles him out of near-sleep and he blinks fearfully the doors, then looks over at... Cheeon, who is leaning against the wall, looking at him.

Slone, wiping his eyes with the back of his hand, comes o of the REAR ENTRANCE with Cheeon. The two Deputies, Core, finally Marium follow close behind. They cluster by CHEEON’S TRUCK, waiting as Slone gulps so fresh air, collects himself, looking up at the stars. Marium approaches.

I’m sorry, Vernon. We’ll keep you informed. It’s a state-wide all points, so...it’ll be over soon. Slone just stares at him.  43. Marium extends his hand. Slone looks down at it, dead-eye and finally takes it for a perfunctory shake. Core has turned away from this, is already heading off toward’s MARIUM’S TRUCK when...

Wolf Man. Core stops, looks back. Slone steps forward. Core watches him, unsure of what’s coming... Slone extends his hand to him. Core hesitates, takes it, to look the taller man in the eye but only barely. Marium notes the moment and, with that, he and Core get i his truck and pull away. Once they’re out of sight... The Fat Deputy produces a FLASK, drinks and offers it to Slone, who drinks, and passes it on to Cheeon...
Fucking thing like this. Can you figure her mind? Jesus God.
You know, uh, I read post-partum can go on for years sometimes.

Shut the fuck up, Mike. (as Cheeon passes him the flask back) Don’t worry, Vern. We’ll get her, I promise you that. Very casually, Cheeon brings out a .45 AUTO, hands it to Slone, and SLONE SHOOTS THE FAT DEPUTY IN THE FACE. BAM.

Don' t-- SLONE SHOOTS THE YOUNG DEPUTY IN THE FACE. BAM. As Cheeon unlocks and opens the bed of his TRUCK, Slone SHOOTS EACH OF THE FALLEN MEN EACH ONCE MORE. BAM, BAM. As Cheeon starts the engine, Slone walks back towards the REAR ENTRANCE with that smoking pistol in his fist.

INT. MARIUM’S TRUCK (MOVING) - NIGHT The WIND whistles outside the cab, some bluesy classic ro on the RADIO. But even so, Marium glances briefly in the rearview. Did I hear something back there? He turns the RADIO down, frowning into the rearview. But just black silence out there now.
What?
Nothing. Core coughs, dabs his nose. Looks like shit. Marium notic A NEW SONG begins and Core reaches for the radio dial...
Do you mind? ...-turns it back up when Marium shrugs, Go ahead. CORE (CONT’D) I like this one. Marium drives on, listening to the song.
Me too.

Pitch-blackness is split by HEADLIGHTS crawling towards u revealing this hidden pass through thick woods. CHEEON’S TRUCK jerks to a halt, splashing its LIGHTS onto MASSIVE ICY DRIFT. Slone and Cheeon hop out, moving fast. A PICK AXE and a SHOVEL are yanked out. CHOPPING into the HILL in a tight, steady rhythm--kak, kak, kak, kak--until SHALLOW SLOT is cleared. Cheeon shoulders a RECTANGULAR WOODEN BOX from the truck plain but expertly crafted, and fits it into the slot. And then Slone moves to the truck, slowing as he bends to remove BAILEY’S BLANKET-WRAPPED BODY. He lays him gently inside the BOX, folds the blanket back removes his glove...and lays his hand on Bailey for a mom  45. He replaces the blanket and turns away, blasted white in HEADLIGHTS as he moves back towards the truck while Cheeo in the background, power drills a lid onto the box. VZZ2Z

CHEEON’S TRUCK glides through Keelut like a black shark. A FACE in a cabin peers at them passing, quickly looks aw INT. CHEEON’S TRUCK (MOVING) - NIGHT Cheeon pulls up to the end of the road, to the Slone Cabi throws it in park and passes Slone a SET OF KEYS.
Heat shed behind the school. Registered to a cousin. Full tank. If you gotta go to ground, Shan’s still got his place.
I won't. They clasp hands, eyes locked, and share a tiny nod. This communion. But just before Slone pops the door...
I am sorry about Alasie. Cheeon blinks once but otherwise might as well be stone. SLONE (CONT’D) It’s not right you don’t have her body.
Right’s got nothing to do with anything. You know this. Yes, Slone does know this.
THE FRONT DOOR is sealed with an X of yellow police tape Slone passes by, circling back to--  46.

THE REAR DOOR where he enters, another wad of police tape his hand. He moves in a sure but unhurried way. We follow him, catching fast glimpses of what he does. Time is brok INSTANT COFFEE, boiling water going into a mug. A SANDWICH, hard bread and cold cuts slapped together, Sl chewing mechanically, gulping coffee. IN THE BEDROOM MIRROR he peels off his bandage and applie antiseptic cream to his HEALING GUNSHOT WOUND. A CUPBOARD is opened and Slone (now with a fresh bandage his neck) retrieves a 9MM HANDGUN and BOX OF AMMO. A DUFFEL BAG is opened and the 9MM, a 12 GAUGE AUTOLOADER REMINGTON RIFLE, the AR-15 and VARIOUS AMMO go inside. THE COMPOUND BOW is grabbed, a QUIVER of arrows. FROM A FOOTLOCKER, socks, leggings, Maglite, binoculars. FROM A DRAWER, a POLAROID PHOTO: Medora, posed on the edg a river in hiking gear, smiling awkwardly. A WICKER BASKET, pawing inside it until he brings back a of MEDORA’S UNDERWEAR. He inhales them, precisely. And then sees something else, bends to get it...one of BAILEY’S LITTLE T-SHIRTS. His hand closes tightly on it. EXT. ILLANAQ’S HUT - NIGHT ILLANAQ waits before her hut, FIRELIGHT crackling behind for a semi-silhouette. She sees something and shuffles ba inside because... Slone is coming this way, inexorably, through the snow. INT. ILLANAQ’S HUT - SAME Illanagq sits by her fireplace, a halved oil drum turned its side. Pelts, cordwood, leather-bound books as furnitu She holds a faceless HEX DOLL for comfort. THE WIND stirs sparks and then Slone is sitting across fr her, firelight gleaming on the blade of his Bowie knife.  47.
You come to punish the old witch, Vernon Slone? I’m no witch. You think I knew? You think I could have stopped her? An old woman? Slone says nothing. She spits on her own floor, smirks.
Go to your father’s grave and ask him. Take your wrath to the gods, to the wolves. To yourself and end it. Slone says nothing. She rattles the hex doll at him, as i scold him.

That boy’s fate was foretold in the ice. So was hers. And yours. You should have died there in the sand but you did not accept that. You came home to see. Slone says nothing. She shifts, growing less sure, less haughty. She reaches for a PILL BOTTLE, swallows one dry.

This is not the first time the wolves came. Before, the white men called it influenza. We called it peelak. I was a little girl. Half the village, their bodies in igloos on the hill, for proper burial after breakup. I pulled them there on my father’s sled. But the wolves came at night and broke the igloos. In the morning, the hillside was scattered with the pieces of their bodies. There is no proper burial after that. That is our history here. Slone says nothing. She pleads in a whisper...
You cannot blame an old woman for it. Slone rises, his body filling the smoky space of the hut.  48.
A 4x4 is tucked into this dark, hidden turnaround, lights but its ENGINE idling, exhaust smoke swirling around it..
Vernon is curled inside it under many quilts, eyes shut t with BAILEY’S SHIRT clamped over his nose, breathing it i Even with the heat on, his breath fogs. FADE TO BLACK.
THE MUTED TV SHOWS A PIXELATED IRAQ, the terrible green strobe of a shock and awe bombing campaign.
Good afternoon. Linguistics.
Professor Core, please.
Who's calling?
Her father.

(chilly, after a beat) One moment. THE SIDE TABLE is cluttered with snotty tissues, half-emp NyQuil, paper cups of cold tea. A half-eaten chocolate ba We can hear the crackly HOLD MUSIC over the phone line. AN OFFICIAL POLICE FORM, ‘Statement of Witness’, blank ex for Core’s contact information, lays on the chair with a The hold music cuts and--
(CONT'D)
I'm sorry, she's not available, may I take a message?

(quiet defeat) No, thank you.  49. Click. Core lays curled and sweaty in bed, gazing at the televis Fearfully hypnotized. He coughs softly, rolls away from i CLOSE ON CORE as he stares straight ahead at something el something in near focus. His expression remains the same. CLOSE ON CORE’S WIFE, curled beside him, her frozen-moan only inches away from his. CLOSE ON CORE, staring at her, his face tightening with s impossible question. CLOSE ON MEDORA, who is now the one curled beside him, looking back at him with a plain, answering kind of look. HIGH SHOT, looking down on Core in bed, tangled in the thrashed-up sheets. He is, of course, all alone here. A long beat like that, and then... He pushes himself up, reaches for the police form and pen A FLASH OF THE FORM: ‘...is true to the best of my knowledge,’ with a space for writing below. Not yours. The boy’s. Slone’s eyes sharpen and narrow. He seems to coil.
What do you know about that?
Just a feelin’. The Drifter smiles past Slone’s shoulder, out at THEIR CA where MEDORA is silhouetted in the orange-lighted window.
Looks warm.
Best find a home of your own, then.  72.
I don’t mean the house. His tone is not lascivious, though, it’s damn near revere But Slone leans closer, his voice dropping to a low monot
Look into my face now. Believe what I tell you. I will end your every day. Do you believe me when I say that to you? The Drifter nods, placating. Sure, sure.
Move on. Slone rises and heads back. The Drifter watches him go.
Medora lays asleep on the bed, curled on her side under a quilt in the mostly-dark room. Slone watches her from the doorway with something almost fear.
Slone is a wraith cutting through the woods, quick and silent, garbed in black. The DYING CAMPFIRE glows just be the trees: he’s circling around behind it.

Slone melts out of the forest, his BOWIE KNIFE a shining sliver in one fist as he angles in on the DRIFTER’S TENT. He crouches, listening. INT./EXT. DRIFTER’S TENT - SAME Slone snaps open the flap but-- It’s empty. Looking closer, he sees-- Resting on the filthy sleeping bag, crudely carved from a of soap, a tiny FERTILITY FIGURE.  73. Dread pooling on his face, Slone looks back to the cabin.
CLOSE ON MEDORA, a film of perspiration on her face, winc in discomfort as she comes blearily half-awake to see... A SHAPE in the doorway, looking in at her.
.-.-what’re you doing, baby? THE SHAPE doesn’t answer. She sits up, achingly holding her belly.
.--oh God...something’s happening. And now, her eyes adjusting, she sees that it’s not Slone standing in the doorway. Her face hardens in terror.
There’s money in a jar by the sink. Fifty dollars. And food. The Drifter’s manner is calmly sympathetic, comforting ev
I came to warn you. The boy can’t live. She flinches as he reaches into his coat, pulls SOMETHING and tosses it onto the bed before her... It’s THE SHAMAN’S MASK.
The mask is yours. Someone made it for you. She gapes at the upside-down WOLF FACE in revulsion.
Wear the mask and you’1l know what you have to do. A SILVER TRIANGLE EMERGES FROM WITHIN THE DRIFTER’S THROA HOLDS THERE, AND THEN WITHDRAWS BACK INSIDE HIS NECK. He looks so surprised.  74.

head_text.subj: BLOOD GURGLES FROM THE SLIT THAT REMAINS IN HIS ADAM'S AP
AS HE DROPS TO THE FLOOR.

text: SLONE is behind him clutching the blood-slicked BOWIE KNI Medora CRIES in sudden pain and throws back the quilt, th WOLF MASK spilling off to the floor. Her sheets are soaked with AMNIOTIC FLUID. Slone rushes to her. LOW ANGLE on the WOLF MASK and the DEAD DRIFTER, canted together and forgotten on the floor as, in the background Slone bends lovingly over Medora and she SCREAMS AGAIN...

HER SCREAM ECHOES INTO THIS TIME as Slone stares out his truck, living that memory, suffused in cold orange light. He looks to the passenger seat and reaches for... A FOLDED MAP, revealing that POLAROID of Medora beneath. We’1l notice the COMPOUND BOW wedged behind the seat, his DUFFEL BAG with the guns in it. As he studies the map... SLONE’S POV (MACRO ON THE MAP) moves from a splash of LAK until it lands on A SMALL DOT: ‘KMC-13’. He sets the map down, puts the truck in gear. EXT. LAKE — SAME SLONE’S TRUCK pulls away from this seemingly infinite bod water where the Sun collapses into molten copper.
SNOW CHAINS rattle and groan on the tires as... SLONE’S 4x4 crawls slowly along under a canopy of cottonw snowy, unmarked wilderness.

SLONE’S 4x4 pulls in on a snowy road as we see--  75. THE SMALL VALLEY the road winds through, a V-shape cut in the earth with a CLUSTER OF DARK CORRODED WOODEN BUILDING spreading up one side, interconnected one atop the other some long-dead fungal growth. A paint-peeling SIGN: CAMP #13 - Kennebeck & McCarthy Cor There’s still some daylight left in the sky above but dow here, in the valley, it feels like an early nightfall.
Slone scans the dead, lightless camp as he drives. To his right, a ways up the unconstructed side of the valley, FIRELIGHT DANCES...seemingly from within the Earth. He drives on.

Slone parks before this leaning TWO-STORY BUILDING with ‘ painted by hand above the door, inky light in its sooty windows. He gets out, glances around, sees... A CORRUGATED SHED with a pyramid of CAR BATTERIES outside Empty WOOD PALLETS stacked for firewood, a half-collapsed QUONSET HUT, a SCHOOL BUS slowly sinking into the ground.

Slone enters, closing the door quickly to shut out the co THE INNKEEPER (50s) looks up from her table: she’s stout, overalls and fleece, with wild Brillo hair and Coke-bottl glasses, reading a celebrity magazine from 10 years ago.
(amused) Late in the season for travelers. As Slone crosses to her...
Where you coming from?
Keelut.
There’s no road from there to here. Not directly.  76.
Not directly, no. He looks around, takes in the room: kerosene lamps, lynx pelts, a broken chair burning in the fireplace. It dawns him...
I was here when I was a child. With my father. We visited this camp. I remember it. She squints at him, trying to place his face. He brings out the POLAROID, shows it to her. She chuckles
Was she here?
They don’t got women in Keelut, gotta crawl all the way up here for a piece? Slone just stares at her. As she applies some ChapStick, looking him up and down...
(almost to herself) You are a handsome one, aren’t ya.
Can you help me?

I don’t have any bread, gotta warn ya, the plane hasn’t been back in two weeks. But I have a room to let. I’d make sure it’s warm enough. She lets that hang for a moment, grinning. He turns away, heads for the door, but as he pulls it ope He stops.
Yeah, she was here. Closes the door. Turns.
That one in your picture there. They don’t make that kind of film anymore.  77.
When?
Two nights ago. Said she wanted to see our Indian Hunter. He’s not really Indian, though, he’s just John.
Why?
Didn’t share that and I didn’t ask. Struck me as damned skittish, you want the truth. Slone absorbs this, and then...
I want to stay in the room she took.
Only two rooms. Other one’s mine. I hadn’t actually changed the sheets yet, hope you don’t mind. As she rummages around for the ROOM KEY...
I don’t know about your vehicle's battery but you might wanna get it in the shed before it drops tonight. Radio says it’s a storm.

The Innkeeper unlocks it, lets Slone enter. He stands the with his DUFFEL BAG, looking at the dingy wood-slat room. He sets his bag down (with an audible clink! of gunmetal inside) and slowly approaches the BED. She watches as... He draws back the covers, bends low, and BREATHES in deep the scent of the sheets. After a beat...he turns back to

The Indian Hunter? Something wild in his eyes makes her swallow.  78. EXT. ABANDONED MINING CAMP —- NIGHT LOOKING UP the slope of the valley wall to a CAVE MOUTH: animal-skin curtains and FIRELIGHT shimmering inside. TILT DOWN to find SLONE hiking steadily up towards it. INT. HUNTER JOHN’S CAVE - NIGHT HUNTER JOHN (60s) looks up from a steaming stew pot, grin in welcome. Imp-eyed, skeletal and bald with a beard to h chest, dressed all in animal skins. Slone enters, stooping low and unzipping his coat in the claustrophobic warmth of several smoking braziers. It’s packed with stuff: bear skins and hunting rifles, folk ar and motor parts, old National Geographics and Playboys. And MASKS. Dozens, various crude ANIMAL FACES of wood and cloth and pelt, displayed on the wall. Slone sees them.

Come eat. He ladles up a second bowl for Slone, offers a spot to si Slone takes a bite, watches Hunter John slurp the broth. Eventually... HUNTER JOHN (CONT’D) She knows you’re coming for her. She told me what she did, too. That’s why she came to me. For counsel. She had one of my masks. I don’t know how she got it. I share them with travelers and they find their way to who needs them.
You let her go from here.

Not my business what she did. There’s no decree in the country. It don’t reach here. I help who comes asking. He peers across at Slone, a small knowing smile. HUNTER JOHN (CONT’D) I remember you, traveler. Just a little tyke last time you were here. All that yellow hair?  79.
Why did we come?

To see me. Your father wanted wolf’s oil. It was for you. Did you know that? He said you were unnatural. That was his word. An Indian witch from his village said wolf’s oil could cure you. Did it work? I gave him the oil. Slone stares at him. He--what? For just an instant there looked as if he might shed tears. He clears his throat.
(so soft) Where did she go?

Not my business. I traded her my truck and I’d say I got the better deal. Fixed her up with some boots I'd made. She left her mask, though. Hunter John gestures vaguely with his spoon into a corner HUNTER JOHN (CONT’D) You're welcome to it, boy. As Slone looks back and RISES OUT OF FRAME, Hunter John returns his attention to his meal... HUNTER JOHN (CONT’D) When was the last time you wore a mask? I can see you need to let the wolf out a little. We all do, out here. It’s truth. Hunter John looks up to see Slone, hunched beneath the lo cave roof with his back to him. But turning slowly around now...with MEDORA’S WOLF MASK o his face and the 9MM PISTOL in his hand. They stare at each other in flickering firelight. EXT. ABANDONED MINING CAMP —- NIGHT LOOKING UP AT THE CAVE as--bang.bang.--GUNSHOTS ECHO from dancing light within and wash down over the camp.  80.
The Innkeeper looks up from a magazine, hearing the shots EXT. HUNTER JOHN’S CAVE - NIGHT Slone-as-Wolf emerges, his eyes black pits in the mask, a
